intro: Stephanomeria runcinata var. parishii, commonly known as the Parish's globemallow, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes mallows and hibiscus. The plant is characterized by its woolly, gray-green foliage and showy yellow flowers that bloom in late summer. It typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to arid environments. This variety is distinguished by its narrow, lance-shaped leaves and is often found in coastal scrub and chaparral ecosystems.
